body:
Problem:  An accidental key press can dismiss a routed message to be
          shown in full before the user was able to read it.
          'verbose' message routing based on an outdated condition results
          in "last_set" messages being separated from its message pair.
Solution: Show a message to be shown in full in the cmdline window instead
          of the pager. Keep it there and update the spill indicator when
          the message is dismissed.
          Remove the 'verbose' message routing.

Fix #34682
Fix #34760

comment_regular_data.body:
> Show a message to be shown in full in the cmdline window instead of the pager.

I went back and forth a couple of times on whether to show the full message in the cmdline or pager window (spent a lot of time redoing the implementation only to change it again after finding shortcomings with it...). It's a bit of a trade-off (both in implementation and usability) but in the end I think it makes most sense to optimize for the dismissal case rather than the user wanting to enter the pager (which I assume to be less common).

I feel that messages that we want to show in full but won't fit in the cmdline (which is clipped somewhat arbitrarily to half the available 'lines' currently), should still be routed to the pager to be entered immediately. E.g. when the user types `:map<CR>`, showing just part of the mappings to be dismissed seems wrong.

Updated to do so. Also supporting clicking the cmdline with the mouse to enter the pager again.

> E.g. when the user types `:map<CR>`, showing just part of the mappings to be dismissed seems wrong.

If it's that bothersome, we can introduce 'messageheight' or whatever, as already described in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34281 .

Meanwhile, showing "only part of the mappings" is unavoidable if they take up more than fullscreen anyway. 

So please, let's stop trying to be smart about this. Simple rules are a much better UX. The rule is: to enter the pager, hit `g<` (we can discuss more ways to opt-in later).

> If it's that bothersome, we can introduce 'messageheight' or whatever, as already described in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34281 .

> Meanwhile, showing "only part of the mappings" is unavoidable if they take up more than fullscreen anyway.

'messageheight' cannot help in immediately entering the pager for command output that will not fit in the dismissable cmdline, but reasonably should be shown in full. I think that applies at least to all "list_cmd" messages, that's the entire purpose of that message kind.

> Simple rules are a much better UX. The rule is: to enter the pager, hit g< (we can discuss more ways to opt-in later).

This dismissable full message logic only applies to messages that we have already determined should be shown in full. The spill indicator -> `g<` UX applies to all other messages.

Not being able to immediately scroll down in `list_cmd` output that can't be shown in full as a dismissable cmdline message would be quite a regression w.r.t. the message grid IMO.

> I think that applies at least to all "list_cmd" messages, that's the entire purpose of that message kind.

That might have made sense before https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34281 specified a more predictable behavior. But now it seems to make less sense for arbitrary commands `:ls` to require "full screen" (not to mention "enter the pager") while others don't.

> Not being able to immediately scroll down in `list_cmd` output that can't be shown in full as a dismissable cmdline message would be quite a regression w.r.t. the message grid IMO.

If people want this kind of thing they can opt-in to it somehow, later.

What I'm trying to avoid is that we *start* with a random assortment of arbitrary decisions. It is easier to reason about, and explain, a simple system that allows customization, rather than an unpredictable system.

> 'messageheight' cannot help in immediately entering the pager for command output that will not fit in the dismissable cmdline

'messageheight' is essentially a configurable "treat this height as fullscreen".

Anyway, the discussion is somewhat muddled because we're talking about both fullscreen and "enter the pager". Let's leave "enter the pager" as a fully separate PR.

> 'messageheight' is essentially a configurable "treat this height as fullscreen".

Yes, I just don't think it makes sense to treat any height other than the message height as full screen for a list of items that was specifically requested.

> That might have made sense before #34281 specified a more predictable behavior. But now it seems to make less sense for arbitrary commands `:ls` to require "full screen" (not to mention "enter the pager") while others don't.

It is not arbitrary commands. Surely we are capable of assigning a few of our own commands the `list_cmd` kind. If it feels random to you please point out specific commands. The decision to show the message in full is already gated behind this logic:
```lua
-- Typed "inspection" messages should be shown in full.
local inspect = { 'echo', 'echomsg', 'lua_print' }
local full = kind == 'list_cmd' or (ext.cmd.level >= 0 and vim.tbl_contains(inspect, kind))
```

Then this PR decides to route it to the pager if it doesn't reasonably fit in an extended dismissable cmdline.
```lua
local tar = hidden and height < math.ceil(vim.o.lines * 0.5) and 'cmd' or 'pager'
``` 

Are you objecting to the former or the latter? Removing the former would either always or never show the dismissable cmdline message, which I thought we didn't want. To me the latter is just objectively more useful behavior and should be opt-out if anything (given that the former logic is restrictive enough to just commands that we want to show in full).

> Are you objecting to the former or the latter?

Objecting to anything that focuses the pager.

I mentioned somewhere that we could explore making it easier to opt-in to the pager, e.g. : 

- `<shift-enter>` from the ":" cmdline 
- `<enter>` while the non-focused messages are displayed (during the "any key will dismiss" `on_key` state)

> local tar = hidden and height < math.ceil(vim.o.lines * 0.5) and 'cmd' or 'pager'

If a big list of errors is echo'd, or a plugin prints a screenfull of `:!` or `system()` output, will this focus the pager? 100% don't want that. (btw what does `tar` mean?)

> Objecting to anything that focuses the pager.

Updated to no longer do this then. Had to make sure the spill indicator is also shown when it spills the vim.on_key cmdline, and update it when it is dismissed. That way if feels OK to me.

Using `tar` as short for "target".
